title: The Gospel of Mark - Chapter 1 Commentary

verses.text: The beginning of the gospel of Jesus Christ, the Son of God.
verses.commentary: Mark introduces the gospel as the 'beginning' of the good news about Jesus Christ, emphasizing His divine identity as the Son of God.

verses.text: As it is written in Isaiah the prophet: 'I will send my messenger ahead of you, who will prepare your way'—'a voice of one calling in the wilderness, Prepare the way for the Lord, make straight paths for him.'
verses.commentary: John the Baptist fulfills Old Testament prophecies (Mal. 3:1, Isa. 40:3), preparing the way for Jesus by preaching repentance. Mark penetrates to the core of John’s role as the forerunner (John 1:19-23).

verses.text: And so John came, baptizing in the desert region and preaching a baptism of repentance for the forgiveness of sins.
verses.commentary: John’s baptism signifies repentance and forgiveness, drawing crowds from Judea and Jerusalem (Acts 19:4).

verses.text: The whole Judean countryside and all the people of Jerusalem went out to him... preaching that a more powerful one was coming.
verses.commentary: John’s attire resembles Elijah (II Kings 1:8), reinforcing his prophetic role. He points to Jesus as the greater one who baptizes with the Holy Spirit (John 1:29).

verses.text: At that time Jesus came from Nazareth in Galilee and was baptized by John in the Jordan. As Jesus was coming up out of the water, he saw heaven being torn open and the Spirit descending on him like a dove.
verses.commentary: Jesus’ baptism marks the start of His public ministry. The heavens tearing open and the Spirit’s descent signify divine approval (Joel 2:28-29).

verses.text: And a voice came from heaven: 'You are my Son, whom I love; with you I am well pleased.'
verses.commentary: God’s voice affirms Jesus as His beloved Son, echoing Psalm 2:7 and Isaiah 42:1, highlighting His divine mission (Heb. 10:5-7).

verses.text: At once the Spirit sent him out into the wilderness, and he was in the wilderness forty days, being tempted by Satan.
verses.commentary: Jesus’ temptation demonstrates His humanity and divine strength. Mark’s brief account, likely from Peter, omits details found in Matthew and Luke (Luke 4:1-2).

verses.text: After John was put in prison, Jesus went into Galilee, proclaiming the good news of God. 'The time has come,' he said. 'The kingdom of God has come near. Repent and believe the good news!'
verses.commentary: Jesus begins His ministry after John’s arrest, proclaiming the nearness of God’s kingdom and calling for repentance and faith (Matt. 3:2).

verses.text: As Jesus walked beside the Sea of Galilee, he saw Simon and his brother Andrew... 'Come, follow me,' Jesus said, 'and I will send you out to fish for people.'
verses.commentary: Jesus calls Simon, Andrew, James, and John, who immediately leave their nets, showing the urgency and authority of His call (Luke 5:10).

verses.text: They went to Capernaum, and when the Sabbath came, Jesus went into the synagogue and began to teach... A man in their synagogue who was possessed by an impure spirit cried out.
verses.commentary: Jesus teaches with authority and casts out a demon, astonishing the crowd. His power over evil spirits sets Him apart from other teachers (Matt. 4:13).

verses.text: As soon as they left the synagogue, they went with James and John to the home of Simon and Andrew. Simon’s mother-in-law was in bed with a fever, and they immediately told Jesus about her.
verses.commentary: Jesus heals Peter’s mother-in-law, demonstrating personal compassion and divine power, enabling her to serve immediately (Matt. 8:15).

subsections.subsection: Healing Many and Cleansing a Leper (1:32-45)

verses.text: That evening after sunset the people brought to Jesus all the sick and demon-possessed.
verses.commentary: Jesus heals many in Capernaum, but avoids popularity to focus on preaching, as it aligns with His mission (Matt. 8:20).

verses.text: Very early in the morning, while it was still dark, Jesus got up, left the house and went off to a solitary place, where he prayed.
verses.commentary: Jesus prioritizes prayer and moves to preach in other towns, showing His commitment to His broader mission (Luke 4:43).

verses.text: A man with leprosy came to him and begged him on his knees, 'If you are willing, you can make me clean.'
verses.commentary: Jesus cleanses a leper, moved by compassion, but instructs him to follow Mosaic law, highlighting faith and obedience (Luke 4:43).
